Units Operations Package

This section documents all process unit classes in SPROCLIB.

Base Classes

Base classes for SPROCLIB - Standard Process Control Library

This module provides the abstract base class for all process models.

Author: Thorsten Gressling <gressling@paramus.ai> License: MIT License

class unit.base.ProcessModel.ProcessModel(name: str = 'ProcessModel')[source]

Bases: ABC

Abstract base class for process models.

__init__(name: str = 'ProcessModel')[source]

Initialize process model.

Parameters:

name – Model name for identification

abstract dynamics(t: float, x: <MagicMock id='2769528468640'>, u: <MagicMock id='2769528521648'>) → <MagicMock id='2769528525392'>[source]

Define the process dynamics dx/dt = f(t, x, u).

Parameters:

  • t – Time

  • x – State variables

  • u – Input variables

Returns:

State derivatives dx/dt

abstract steady_state(u: <MagicMock id='2769528529136'>) → <MagicMock id='2769528532880'>[source]

Calculate steady-state values for given inputs.

Parameters:

u – Input variables

Returns:

Steady-state values

simulate(t_span: ~typing.Tuple[float, float], x0: <MagicMock id='2769528362992'>, u_func: ~typing.Callable[[float], <MagicMock id='2769528368800'>], t_eval: <MagicMock id='2769528560944'> | None = None) → Dict[str, <MagicMock id='2769528588768'>][source]

Simulate the process model.

Parameters:

  • t_span – Time span (t_start, t_end)

  • x0 – Initial conditions

  • u_func – Function returning inputs as function of time

  • t_eval – Time points for output (optional)

Returns:

Dictionary with ‘t’, ‘x’, ‘u’ arrays

get_info() → Dict[str, Any][source]

Get model information summary.

Returns:

Dictionary with model information

update_parameters(**kwargs)[source]

Update model parameters.

Parameters:

**kwargs – Parameter updates

Pumps and Compressors

Pump module for SPROCLIB - Standard Process Control Library

This module contains various pump models for liquid pumping operations.

Tanks and Vessels

Tank Models for SPROCLIB

This package contains tank models for liquid storage and processing applications in chemical process simulation and control.

Available Tank Models: - Tank: Single gravity-drained tank - InteractingTanks: Two tanks in series

Author: Thorsten Gressling <gressling@paramus.ai> License: MIT License

class unit.tank.Tank(A: float = 1.0, C: float = 1.0, name: str = 'GravityTank')[source]

Bases: ProcessModel

Gravity-drained tank model.

__init__(A: float = 1.0, C: float = 1.0, name: str = 'GravityTank')[source]

Initialize gravity-drained tank.

Parameters:

  • A – Cross-sectional area [m²]

  • C – Discharge coefficient [m²/min]

  • name – Model name

dynamics(t: float, x: <MagicMock id='2769529001632'>, u: <MagicMock id='2769529005376'>) → <MagicMock id='2769529009168'>[source]

Tank dynamics: dh/dt = (q_in - C*sqrt(h))/A

Parameters:

  • t – Time

  • x – [height]

  • u – [q_in] - inlet flow rate

Returns:

[dh/dt]

steady_state(u: <MagicMock id='2769528963872'>) → <MagicMock id='2769528967664'>[source]

Steady-state height: h = (q_in/C)²

Parameters:

u – [q_in] - inlet flow rate

Returns:

[h_ss] - steady-state height

calculate_outlet_flow(h: float) → float[source]

Calculate outlet flow rate based on tank height.

Parameters:

h – Tank height [m]

Returns:

Outlet flow rate [m³/min]

calculate_volume(h: float) → float[source]

Calculate tank volume based on height.

Parameters:

h – Tank height [m]

Returns:

Tank volume [m³]

calculate_time_constant(h_op: float) → float[source]

Calculate linearized time constant at operating point.

Parameters:

h_op – Operating height [m]

Returns:

Time constant [min]

class unit.tank.InteractingTanks(A1: float = 1.0, A2: float = 1.0, C1: float = 1.0, C2: float = 1.0, name: str = 'InteractingTanks')[source]

Bases: ProcessModel

Two interacting tanks in series.

__init__(A1: float = 1.0, A2: float = 1.0, C1: float = 1.0, C2: float = 1.0, name: str = 'InteractingTanks')[source]

Initialize interacting tanks model.

Parameters:

  • A1 – Cross-sectional areas [m²]

  • A2 – Cross-sectional areas [m²]

  • C1 – Discharge coefficients [m²/min]

  • C2 – Discharge coefficients [m²/min]

  • name – Model name

dynamics(t: float, x: <MagicMock id='2769529040256'>, u: <MagicMock id='2769529044048'>) → <MagicMock id='2769529113392'>[source]

Interacting tanks dynamics: dh1/dt = (q_in - C1*sqrt(h1))/A1 dh2/dt = (C1*sqrt(h1) - C2*sqrt(h2))/A2

Parameters:

  • t – Time

  • x – [h1, h2] - tank heights

  • u – [q_in] - inlet flow rate

Returns:

[dh1/dt, dh2/dt]

steady_state(u: <MagicMock id='2769529117184'>) → <MagicMock id='2769529120976'>[source]

Steady-state heights for interacting tanks.

Parameters:

u – [q_in] - inlet flow rate

Returns:

[h1_ss, h2_ss] - steady-state heights

Valves and Flow Control

Valve Models for SPROCLIB

This package contains valve models for flow control and process regulation in chemical process simulation and control.

Available Valve Models: - ControlValve: Variable control valve for flow regulation - ThreeWayValve: Three-way valve for flow routing

Author: Thorsten Gressling <gressling@paramus.ai> License: MIT License

class unit.valve.ControlValve(Cv_max: float = 100.0, valve_type: str = 'linear', dead_time: float = 0.5, time_constant: float = 2.0, rangeability: float = 50.0, name: str = 'ControlValve')[source]

Bases: ProcessModel

Control valve model with flow coefficient (Cv) characteristics and dead-time.

Features: - Flow coefficient-based flow calculations - Valve position dead-time modeling - Pressure drop compensation - Valve characteristics (linear, equal percentage, quick opening) - Saturation limits

__init__(Cv_max: float = 100.0, valve_type: str = 'linear', dead_time: float = 0.5, time_constant: float = 2.0, rangeability: float = 50.0, name: str = 'ControlValve')[source]

Initialize control valve model.

Parameters:

  • Cv_max – Maximum flow coefficient (gpm/psi^0.5)

  • valve_type – Valve characteristic (‘linear’, ‘equal_percentage’, ‘quick_opening’)

  • dead_time – Valve position dead-time (seconds)

  • time_constant – Valve actuator time constant (seconds)

  • rangeability – Valve rangeability (Cv_max/Cv_min)

  • name – Valve identifier

dynamics(t: float, x: <MagicMock id='2769529271552'>, u: <MagicMock id='2769469910256'>) → <MagicMock id='2769529267952'>[source]

Valve dynamics with dead-time and first-order lag.

State: [actual_position, flow_rate] Input: [position_command, upstream_pressure, downstream_pressure, density]

Parameters:

  • t – Time

  • x – [actual_position, flow_rate]

  • u – [position_command, P_upstream, P_downstream, rho]

Returns:

[d(position)/dt, d(flow)/dt]

steady_state(u: <MagicMock id='2769529263920'>) → <MagicMock id='2769529144432'>[source]

Calculate steady-state valve position and flow.

Parameters:

u – [position_command, P_upstream, P_downstream, rho]

Returns:

[position, flow_rate]

get_flow_coefficient(position: float) → float[source]

Get flow coefficient for given valve position.

get_valve_sizing_info() → Dict[str, float][source]

Get valve sizing information.

Reactors

Continuous Stirred Tank Reactor (CSTR) Model

This module provides a CSTR model with Arrhenius kinetics, energy balance, and heat transfer capabilities.

Author: Thorsten Gressling <gressling@paramus.ai> License: MIT License

class unit.reactor.cstr.CSTR(V: float = 100.0, k0: float = 72000000000.0, Ea: float = 72750.0, R: float = 8.314, rho: float = 1000.0, Cp: float = 0.239, dHr: float = -50000.0, UA: float = 50000.0, name: str = 'CSTR')[source]

Bases: ProcessModel

Continuous Stirred Tank Reactor model.

__init__(V: float = 100.0, k0: float = 72000000000.0, Ea: float = 72750.0, R: float = 8.314, rho: float = 1000.0, Cp: float = 0.239, dHr: float = -50000.0, UA: float = 50000.0, name: str = 'CSTR')[source]

Initialize CSTR model.

Parameters:

  • V – Reactor volume [L]

  • k0 – Arrhenius pre-exponential factor [1/min]

  • Ea – Activation energy [J/gmol]

  • R – Gas constant [J/gmol/K]

  • rho – Density [g/L]

  • Cp – Heat capacity [J/g/K]

  • dHr – Heat of reaction [J/gmol]

  • UA – Heat transfer coefficient [J/min/K]

  • name – Model name

reaction_rate(T: float) → float[source]

Calculate reaction rate constant k(T) = k0 * exp(-Ea/RT)

dynamics(t: float, x: <MagicMock id='2769528647328'>, u: <MagicMock id='2769528717488'>) → <MagicMock id='2769528721184'>[source]

CSTR dynamics: dCA/dt = q/V*(CAi - CA) - k(T)*CA dT/dt = q/V*(Ti - T) + (-dHr)*k(T)*CA/(rho*Cp) + UA*(Tc - T)/(V*rho*Cp)

Parameters:

  • t – Time

  • x – [CA, T] - concentration and temperature

  • u – [q, CAi, Ti, Tc] - flow rate, inlet concentration, inlet temp, coolant temp

Returns:

[dCA/dt, dT/dt]

steady_state(u: <MagicMock id='2769528724976'>) → <MagicMock id='2769528728768'>[source]

Calculate steady-state for CSTR (requires numerical solution).

Parameters:

u – [q, CAi, Ti, Tc] - operating conditions

Returns:

[CA_ss, T_ss] - steady-state concentration and temperature

calculate_conversion(CA: float, CAi: float) → float[source]

Calculate conversion: X = (CAi - CA) / CAi

Parameters:

  • CA – Outlet concentration [mol/L]

  • CAi – Inlet concentration [mol/L]

Returns:

Conversion fraction

calculate_residence_time(q: float) → float[source]

Calculate residence time: tau = V / q

Parameters:

q – Flow rate [L/min]

Returns:

Residence time [min]

calculate_heat_generation(CA: float, T: float) → float[source]

Calculate heat generation rate from reaction.

Parameters:

  • CA – Concentration [mol/L]

  • T – Temperature [K]

Returns:

Heat generation rate [J/min]

get_performance_metrics(x: <MagicMock id='2769528732560'>, u: <MagicMock id='2769528752800'>) → Dict[str, float][source]

Calculate key performance metrics.

Parameters:

  • x – [CA, T] - current state

  • u – [q, CAi, Ti, Tc] - inputs

Returns:

Dictionary with performance metrics

  • rho_cat – Catalyst density [kg/m³]

  • dp – Particle diameter [m]

  • k0 – Pre-exponential factor [m³/kg·s]

  • Ea – Activation energy [J/mol]

  • delta_H – Heat of reaction [J/mol]

  • rho – Fluid density [kg/m³]

  • cp – Heat capacity [J/kg·K]

  • U – Overall heat transfer coefficient [W/m²·K]

  • n_segments – Number of axial segments

  • name – Model name

Calculate reaction rate per unit catalyst mass.

Parameters:

  • CA – Concentration [mol/m³]

  • T – Temperature [K]

Returns:

Reaction rate [mol/kg·s]

Distillation

Binary Distillation Column Model for SPROCLIB

This module provides a binary distillation column model for control design with multiple trays and material balance dynamics.

Author: Thorsten Gressling <gressling@paramus.ai> License: MIT License

class unit.distillation.column.BinaryDistillationColumn.BinaryDistillationColumn(N_trays: int = 20, feed_tray: int = 10, alpha: float = 2.5, tray_holdup: float = 1.0, reflux_drum_holdup: float = 5.0, reboiler_holdup: float = 10.0, feed_flow: float = 100.0, feed_composition: float = 0.5, name: str = 'BinaryDistillationColumn')[source]

Bases: ProcessModel

Simplified binary distillation column model for control design.

__init__(N_trays: int = 20, feed_tray: int = 10, alpha: float = 2.5, tray_holdup: float = 1.0, reflux_drum_holdup: float = 5.0, reboiler_holdup: float = 10.0, feed_flow: float = 100.0, feed_composition: float = 0.5, name: str = 'BinaryDistillationColumn')[source]

Initialize binary distillation column.

Parameters:

  • N_trays – Total number of trays (including reboiler, excluding condenser)

  • feed_tray – Feed tray number (1 = top tray)

  • alpha – Relative volatility (light/heavy) [-]

  • tray_holdup – Liquid holdup per tray [kmol]

  • reflux_drum_holdup – Reflux drum holdup [kmol]

  • reboiler_holdup – Reboiler holdup [kmol]

  • feed_flow – Feed flow rate [kmol/min]

  • feed_composition – Feed composition (mole fraction light component)

  • name – Model name

Distillation Tray Model for SPROCLIB

This module provides a model for individual distillation trays in binary systems with vapor-liquid equilibrium.

Author: Thorsten Gressling <gressling@paramus.ai> License: MIT License

Vapor mole fraction of light component

dynamics(t: float, x: <MagicMock id='2769529151968'>, u: <MagicMock id='2769529158496'>) → <MagicMock id='2769529154464'>[source]

Tray dynamics: component material balance.

State variables: x[0]: Liquid mole fraction of light component on tray

Input variables: u[0]: Liquid flow rate from tray above [kmol/min] u[1]: Liquid composition from tray above [mole fraction] u[2]: Vapor flow rate from tray below [kmol/min] u[3]: Vapor composition from tray below [mole fraction] u[4]: Liquid flow rate from this tray [kmol/min] u[5]: Vapor flow rate from this tray [kmol/min]

Parameters:

  • t – Time

  • x – [x_tray] - liquid composition on tray

  • u – [L_in, x_in, V_in, y_in, L_out, V_out]

Returns:

[dx_tray/dt]

steady_state(u: <MagicMock id='2769529838896'>) → <MagicMock id='2769529835008'>[source]

Calculate steady-state composition.

For steady state: dx/dt = 0 Light_in = Light_out L_in * x_in + V_in * y_in = L_out * x + V_out * y

Parameters:

u – [L_in, x_in, V_in, y_in, L_out, V_out]

Returns:

[x_tray_ss] - steady-state liquid composition
